articles.title: Predictions
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) event schedule for August and September 1979. It details general meetings, board meetings, indoor and outdoor star parties, and the ASTRO*NORTHWEST '79 conference. Key astronomical occurrences like full moons, new moons, and a total lunar eclipse are also noted.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) announces significant leadership changes, including the resignation of Vice-President John Rhodes due to relocation and the subsequent appointments of Frank Dibbell and Bobby Pingerhut, as well as Martha Hanisch as executive secretary. The article also addresses past bulletin errors and implements a solution, clarifies rules for indoor star parties, outlines upcoming activities like a September equipment night, and highlights the club's approaching 25th anniversary. Additionally, it shares member news, including a new book by Ernie Piini and the passing of long-time member Wes Kendall.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: This article provides an update on recent comet activity, noting three new discoveries by both professional and amateur astronomers since late June. It details Comet Bradfield (1979c), including its discovery, estimated brightness, and future observable positions, and briefly mentions the faint Comet Russell (1979d) and the extremely distant Comet Torres (1979e). Additionally, it notes that Comet Meier (1978f) is still visible at 11th magnitude.

articles.title: Comet Meier (1978f)
articles.summary: This document presents an ephemeris for Comet Meier (1978f) from July to September 1979, detailing its right ascension, declination, and estimated visual magnitude. Additionally, it provides general information about comet tails, explaining their formation distance, typical length, and the distinct characteristics of dust and gas tails.

articles.title: SJAA Members' Corner
articles.summary: The inaugural 'SJAA Members' Corner' column is introduced, designed to facilitate member interaction, sharing of interests, and technical assistance. It features profiles of Frank Dibbell, who offers help with telescope making, and Bruno Benassi, an electronics expert specializing in telescope applications and astrophotography. Additionally, the article includes a call from the American Meteor Society for advanced amateur astronomers to observe and photograph the Upsilon Pegasid Meteor Shower.

articles.title: PICNIC!
articles.summary: Over 50 SJAA members and their families gathered for the annual picnic at Sanborn Canyon Park on July 13, enjoying custom-prepared steaks, potluck dishes, and various recreational activities. The event also included officer installation announcements and a planned star party, successfully fostering family involvement and camaraderie among club members. Despite some minor mishaps like an archery ban and poison oak, attendees had a positive experience.

articles.title: Observing the Total Lunar Eclipse
articles.summary: A total lunar eclipse is scheduled for Monday, September 6, 1979, beginning at 12:20 AM and lasting five hours. West Coast observers will have a rare opportunity to view the entire event. The article encourages readers to make valuable observations and provides guidance on how to record and report their findings.

articles.title: Danjon Estimates
articles.summary: Danjon estimates provide a simple visual method for assessing the brightness and color of the Moon during a total lunar eclipse, requiring only the human eye. The article introduces the five-point Danjon scale, ranging from 0 (very dark) to 4 (very bright copper red). It stresses the importance of independent observations to avoid systematic errors in the estimates.

articles.title: Magnitude Estimates
articles.summary: This article outlines a straightforward method for estimating stellar magnitudes, similar to Danjon estimates. The technique involves using simple tools like Christmas tree ornaments or binoculars to compress a star's image, comparing it to known magnitude stars such as Beta Ceti or Fomalhaut, and ensuring consistent viewing methods to compensate for light loss.

articles.title: Crater Timings
articles.summary: This article describes 'crater timings,' a detailed astronomical observation technique requiring equipment like a telescope, lunar map, WWV radio, and tape recorder. By timing shadow contact with crater walls, observers can determine the Earth's oblateness and the expansion of the umbra due to the atmosphere. The author offers a list of predicted crater timings to interested individuals.

articles.title: Other Observations
articles.summary: During past eclipses, observers have noted color bands at the edges of the umbral shadow, with colors appearing in reverse order from typical refraction. Additionally, two reports of Transient Lunar Phenomena (TLP), described as bright specks in lunar maria, have been documented. Future observations of TLP should include precise location, timing, and duration details for reporting.

articles.title: Photography
articles.summary: The article provides a KODAK exposure guide for photographing the moon, detailing specific shutter speeds and f-stops for various ASA film speeds during a full moon, a moon deep in penumbra, and the beginning and full stages of totality during a lunar eclipse. It emphasizes the importance of recording observation parameters for all photos and highlights the particular value of photographs depicting Transient Lunar Phenomena (TLP's).

articles.title: Reporting Results
articles.summary: The article announces a call for observers to submit their astronomical results to Byron Soulsby and David Herald of the Canberra Astronomical Society, with David Ambrose serving as a forwarding contact to reduce postage costs. It also features responses to the 'Question of the Month' regarding how individuals would use unlimited access to the 200-inch telescope, and introduces a new question for the upcoming month.

articles.title: For Sale
articles.summary: A Questar 3.5" telescope, originally owned by Paul Shenkle, is being offered for sale. The telescope features a recently overhauled drive system by Questar, with the seller seeking offers in the $900-1050 range. Interested buyers can contact Les Delong after 6 pm.

articles.title: New Address
articles.summary: The article announces a new address for John Rhodes, now SJAA's northern representative. It primarily details the upcoming 2nd AANC/NASA Joint Conference on Astronomy in September 1979 at NASA Ames Research Facility, outlining activities such as amateur papers, professional talks, displays, tours, and a swap meet, along with registration deadlines and instructions. Additionally, a questionnaire is included to gather member feedback on club meetings and star party preferences.
